TopicTitle: Am I the only one who doesn't understand the new fuel system?

Articles.Content: Just got around to 1.2, made a ship using the fuel line staging Like I have done thousands of times before and did not work. Looked into it, found discussion of the new and improved fuel system where you can manually adjust fueling priority. So I turn advanced tweakables on, go to the VAB anddddd nothing. My fuel still doesn't transfer the way I want to, i thought if I disabled cross feed it would just follow my fuel ducts but it does not, I think I understand fueling priority but if I have 4 radially attached tanks I can not individually change their priority so i cant do the staging like before. Is their a way to disable this new system and revert to the old one? Am I just blatantly missing something? Call me lazy but I prefer the system where you attach, wait for it to burn out, then  detach. Thanks!

Welcome to the forums! This thread is best suited to the Gameplay Questions subforum, you can ask for it to be moved here.

In order for us to help you better, try showing us a few screenshots of what you want to achieve and what you have unsuccessfully tried. That way we can try and reproduce it in our own games, and maybe find a solution that works for you.

Moved over to Gameplay Questions.

Radial tanks mounted on crossfeed-disabled decouplers connected with fuel lines works properly for me without getting into advanced tweakables. Can you give a bit more detail about what fuel routing you are trying to achieve and perhaps share a pic of the affected craft?
Speaking of fuel systems, how does the new fuel delivery system work? I really have no idea what the numbers mean.

43 minutes ago, TheEpicSquared said:

Speaking of fuel systems, how does the new fuel delivery system work? I really have no idea what the numbers mean.

Higher numbers drain first, equal numbers drain together. You can make a rocket more stable by setting the lowest tanks to the highest numbers so the center of mass stays near the front of the rocket during the flight.

10 hours ago, spacerangerbearguy said:

Just got around to 1.2, made a ship using the fuel line staging Like I have done thousands of times before and did not work.

So far in 1.2 my ships with fuel lines work the same as they always have....

12 hours ago, spacerangerbearguy said:

Just got around to 1.2, made a ship using the fuel line staging Like I have done thousands of times before and did not work. Looked into it, found discussion of the new and improved fuel system where you can manually adjust fueling priority. So I turn advanced tweakables on, go to the VAB anddddd nothing. My fuel still doesn't transfer the way I want to, i thought if I disabled cross feed it would just follow my fuel ducts but it does not

Yes, I think we really need a pic here because nothing should have changed if you have disabled cross-feed and placed fuel lines.

12 hours ago, spacerangerbearguy said:

but if I have 4 radially attached tanks I can not individually change their priority so i cant do the staging like before. Is their a way to disable this new system and revert to the old one?

This was the case in 1.1 as well - if you place with symmetry, all of the placed items will act together.

This has annoyed me a touch with landing gear, because if you land on a slope you can't individually set legs to raise or lower.

However, in the VAB/SPH you can still separate out the groups of icons in the staging list (at least... I think I have done this recently) - so you can use 6x symmetry then separate them into pairs for asparagus purposes. Of course, you'll have to manually and individually place the last two fuel lines to the core stack, since symmetry will refuse to let you apply 2x symmetry to a 6x set of boosters.
Still, it's safer and really not difficult to just stick to 2x symmetry when building your staging up.

And with the new fuel routing, no you will not be able to use advanced tweakables on a 6x cluster to make it into an asparagus system.

On Thursday October 27, 2016 at 6:16 AM, spacerangerbearguy said:

…i thought if I disabled cross feed it would just follow my fuel ducts…

You are doing it wrong. Just forget about fuel ducts, they are no longer needed (except in some very special cases).

On Thursday October 27, 2016 at 6:16 AM, spacerangerbearguy said:

I have 4 radially attached tanks I can not individually change their priority so i cant do the staging like before.

Like plusck said, use 2x symetry. Yes, you have to do it twice, but it saves you hassling with fuel ducts so I'd still call it a win.

Let me add:

- the fuel overlay shows all areas where 'crossfeed works'. For now, disregard arrows - treat the green lines as just links that bind fuel tanks into one, big. You may have a few such 'green isles' on your craft. You may isolate or merge them by enabling/disabling crossfeed on decouplers or docking ports, and binding them with fuel pipes.

- Any engine connected will burn as long as there's any fuel left within the 'green zone' it's connected to, no matter where. A booster on a far end may pull fuel from your Mun lander's return tank, if there's a green line connecting the two.

- Now the arrows and the numbers. Higher number means burning sooner. Tanks with these will be depleted first, and the arrows point towards tanks with lower numbers. That does NOT influence engines. If there's still fuel left in the 'group', all engines will burn.

- There's only one exception: fuel pipes are unidirectional. If one tank can only feed fuel to other tanks or outer engines through a fuel pipe, it won't receive fuel from them back. If it has an engine connected to it, it will flame out when the tank is depleted.

- Docking ports have crossfeed enabled by default, and decouplers disabled, but that's all toggleable.

- Fuel feed goes through all node-connected parts (with scarce exceptions with orange message in part's description, 'no fuel crossfeed' or are stack decouplers),

- Fuel does not flow through surface attached parts, unless they are either surface-attached engines attached to fuel tanks, are radial decouplers with crossfeed enabled, or have fuel pipes feeding fuel to them (so e.g. you attach some nose cones around your rocket, put stack-mounted engines under them, and feed fuel into the nose cones, the engines will work.)
